title: 113_hr5629
content: The Act titled "Strengthening Domestic Nuclear Security Act of 2014" introduces amendments to the Homeland Security Act of 2002, specifically focusing on the implementation of the Global Nuclear Detection Architecture domestically. The "Strengthening Domestic Nuclear Security Act of 2014" amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to implement the Global Nuclear Detection Architecture domestically. This includes providing support for planning, organization, equipment, training, and operational assessments to various entities for radiological and nuclear detection capabilities in case of a terror attack. The Securing the Cities Program is also mentioned. The Director for Domestic Nuclear Detection establishes the 'Securing the Cities' program to enhance the ability to detect and prevent radiological or nuclear acts of terror in high-risk urban areas. Jurisdictions are designated based on risk levels, and congressional notification is required. The 'Securing the Cities' program aims to detect and prevent radiological or nuclear acts of terror in high-risk urban areas. The Comptroller General will assess the program's effectiveness and submit a report to congressional committees within one year of enactment. "Procurement reform requires completion of Mission Need Statement and Operational Requirements Document for new system acquisitions. Authorization of $291,000,000 for fiscal years 2015 and 2016." The Act includes provisions for joint interagency review of global nuclear detection architecture, domestic implementation, Securing the Cities program, procurement reform, and authorization of appropriations. It will take effect 30 days after enactment. Reporting requirements are also specified. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to change annual reporting to biennial reporting. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to change reporting from annual to biennial, with adjustments to timeframes in various clauses and subsections.
